metadata.background_text:
Reading the Inaugurals 

         President Clinton's Inaugural Address this month is the 53 rd in the series that began in 1789. All are worth a read--not just the highlights, such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and FDR. They will give you a feeling of being there, not as an omniscient historian of 1997 looking back at 1837 or 1897 but as an ordinary citizen who shares--and is limited by--the information, the concerns, and the values of those times. (Thanks to Columbia University, all the addresses can be found on the Web.) 

         Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln. After 132 years, his second inaugural still brings tears to your eyes and chills your blood. None of the other inaugural addresses are in that league. But by and large they are dignified and intelligent speeches given by articulate men, each in touch with his times and aware that his inauguration was the most solemn occasion of his life. 

         The stance and style of the inaugurals seem to have gone through three phases. The first, lasting until Lincoln, was that of the modest, classic public servant. The second, lasting through William Howard Taft, was of the prosaic government executive. The third, in which we are still, is the phase of the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher. This classification is not waterproof. Theodore Roosevelt may belong in the third phase and Warren G. Harding-Calvin Coolidge-Herbert Hoover in the second. But the trend is clear. 

         On picking up Washington's first inaugural, one is immediately struck by the modesty. He had just been elected unanimously by the Electoral College. He was more respected than any subsequent president has been at the time of his inauguration. And what does he say? 

                         [T]he magnitude and difficulty of the trust to which the voice of my country called me, being sufficient to awaken in the wisest and most experienced of her citizens a distrustful scrutiny into his qualifications, could not but overwhelm with despondence one who (inheriting inferior endowments from nature and unpracticed in the duties of civil administration) ought to be peculiarly conscious of his own deficiencies.              

          None of his successors has made the point as forcefully as that. But echoes are to be found in almost every president for the next 68 years. (John Adams was an exception. He was apparently so envious of Washington that he spent a large part of his address spelling out his own excellent qualifications for the job.) That era ended with Lincoln. Subsequent inaugurals routinely contain protestations of humility, but they are perfunctory and do not sound sincere. 

         The antebellum modesty, while in part a reflection of the conventional etiquette of the time, may also have served a political objective: to alleviate the concerns of those who--in the early days of the republic--feared it might be transformed into a monarchy, and the president into a king. A little later, perhaps after 1820, a new worry arose. Would the power of the federal government be used to interfere with the "peculiar domestic institution" of the Southern states? The presidents' assurance of the limitation of their powers may have been intended to give comfort to those states. 

         Lincoln faced a different situation. With the South already seceding, he could only "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive. It was no time for modesty. Lincoln's successors inherited a federal government with much more authority--and more need to use it--than before the war, and they had less motivation to belittle themselves and their powers. 

         In the third phase, the Inaugural Address metamorphosed from describing the government's policy to inspiring the public's behavior. Presidents recognized--or, at least, believed--that the country had problems they ought to deal with but could not manage by using the instruments of government alone. Thus, in his first inaugural, Woodrow Wilson said: "At last a vision has been vouchsafed us of our life as a whole. We see the bad with the good, the debased and decadent with the sound and the vital. With this vision we approach new affairs." 

         If the country is debased and decadent, the cure has to come from uplifting the people, not from acts of government. Similar diagnoses and prescriptions appear in later inaugurals. 

          Presidents derived their license to serve as leader-preacher from Theodore Roosevelt's remark that the presidency was "a bully pulpit," a remark that did not appear in his Inaugural Address. The metaphor of the pulpit suggests not reading but oral and visual contact between the preacher and his flock. Radio and--even more--television made this possible on a national scale. A telltale sign of the leader-preacher inaugural is the use of the phrase, "Let us ... "--meaning, "You do as I say." This expression appears occasionally throughout the history of inaugurals, but it has hit its stride in recent years. John F. Kennedy repeated it 16 times in his Inaugural Address, and Richard Nixon has it 22 times in his second one. 

         The change in literary style from classical to colloquial can be demonstrated by one statistic. In all the inaugurals from Washington through James Buchanan, the average number of words per sentence was 44. From Lincoln to Wilson it was 34, and since Wilson it has been 25. I do not consider this a deterioration (this article has an average of 17 words per sentence), but it does reflect the change in the size and character of the audience and in the means of communication. William Henry Harrison could talk about the governments of Athens, Rome, and the Helvetic Confederacy and expect his audience to know what he was talking about. That wouldn't be true today. But Harrison's audience would not have known what the Internet was. 

         Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution. Kennedy's trumpet call, "Ask not what your country can do for you: Ask what you can do for your country," has an ironic history. In his inaugural, Harding, surely no model for Kennedy, had said, "Our most dangerous tendency is to expect too little of government, and at the same time do for it too little." And even before he became president, in a speech in 1916, Harding had said, "In the great fulfillment we must have a citizenship less concerned about what the government can do for it and more anxious about what it can do for the nation." 

         Many an issue frets its hour on the inaugural stage and then is heard no more. That includes the Indians, the coastal fortifications, territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, civil-service reform, polygamy, and Prohibition. Some subjects that you expect to appear, don't. Hoover's inaugural, March 4, 1929, gives no hint of economic vulnerability. Roosevelt's second inaugural, Jan. 20, 1937, contains no reference to Hitler or to Germany. But what is most amazing, at least to a reader in 1997, is the silence of the inaugurals on the subject of women. The word "women" does not appear at all until Wilson's first inaugural, and it always appears as part of the phrase "men and women," never as referring to any special concerns of women. Even Harding, the first president to be chosen in an election in which women voted nationally, does not remark on the uniqueness of the fact in his inaugural. 

          One subject that does get ample treatment is taxes. "Taxes," or some equivalent word, appears in 43 of the 52 inaugural addresses to date. Coolidge said in 1925: "The time is arriving when we can have further tax reduction. ... I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." Federal taxes were then about 3 percent of the gross domestic product. Ronald Reagan said essentially the same thing in 1981, when they were 20 percent. 

         The most disturbing aspect of the whole series of inaugurals is what is said and unsaid on the subject of race relations, which Arthur Schlesinger Jr. calls "the supreme American problem." The words "black," "blacks," "Negro," or "race" (as applied to blacks) do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes, 1877. James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" These were rhetorical questions, intended to get the answer "No one!"--as if there were not millions of slaves in America. 

         Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. 

         After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. 

         There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. We should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now, readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today. 

          

            POSTSCRIPT: To read Herbert Stein's analysis of President Clinton's second Inaugural Address, click .
metadata.question: What is the author’s overall thesis about inaugural speeches?
metadata.first_debater_answer: They are a cryptic way to interpret history
metadata.second_debater_answer: They present a snapshot of the views and beliefs of their time

speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

What is the author’s overall thesis about inaugural speeches?

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for “They Are a Cryptic Way to Interpret History”

I. Thesis and Definition  
1. My thesis captures the author’s overarching purpose: inaugurals are not mere time-stamped snapshots but carefully crafted, often coded, texts that reflect, obscure, and shape the historical forces of their eras. The author repeatedly notes what is unsaid—silences on slavery, women, race—and interprets these omissions as meaningful “cryptic” signals, not as neutral reportage.  

II. Evidence of Cryptic Messaging  
1. Omissions as Negative Evidence  
  • “The word ‘women’ does not appear at all until Wilson’s first inaugural… never as referring to any special concerns of women” (<invalid_quote>Background, women silence</invalid_quote>). This repeated silence is a “cryptic” indicator of societal blindness, not a mere byproduct of time.  
  • “The words ‘black,’ ‘blacks,’ ‘Negro,’ or ‘race’… do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes, 1877” (<invalid_quote>Background, race silence</invalid_quote>). The author highlights these gaps to interpret national attitudes, implying that the addresses’ silences are as telling as their words.  

2. Phases and Metaphors  
  • The tripartite classification (modest servant, prosaic executive, leader-preacher) (<invalid_quote>Background, three phases</invalid_quote>) is a hermeneutic model, urging readers to decode ideological shifts rather than passively record them.  
  • The “bully pulpit” metaphor (leader-preacher) signals an intentional move to persuade “uplifting the people” (<invalid_quote>Background, pulpits</invalid_quote>). This is active manipulation of public sentiment, not mere description.  

3. Intertextual Allusions  
  • Reuse of phrases (“Let us…,” “Ask not what…”) without attribution (<invalid_quote>Background, reuse</invalid_quote>) functions as coded appeals to tradition and authority, requiring readers to recognize and interpret these reverberations across time.  

III. Interpretation vs. Description  
1. The author warns that future readers “will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today” (<invalid_quote>Background, humility</invalid_quote>). He suggests inaugurals are historical artifacts requiring interpretation, with hidden biases to be unpacked.  
2. He criticizes inaugurals for “moral obtuseness” (<quote>and moral obtuseness</quote>), implying a need to read between the lines to understand prevailing values and prejudices.  

IV. Rebuttal of “Snapshot” Position  
1. Mere snapshot ignores author’s focus on omissions. A true snapshot would not treat silences (race, women, economy) as “disturbing” or “amazing” signals demanding interpretation.  
2. Snapshot view neglects author’s hermeneutic apparatus: phases, word-per-sentence statistics, metaphorical language, and intertextuality. These analytical tools presuppose complexity and intentionality beyond simple reportage.  
3. If inaugurals were only snapshots, why would the author track “deterioration” of sentence length (<invalid_quote>Background, sentence length</invalid_quote>) and the “telltale sign” of “Let us…” usage? These are indicators for interpretive analysis, not mere period detail.  

V. Conclusion  
The author’s sustained attention to what is both said and unsaid, his analytical models for decoding style and content, and his admonition that future readers must criticize present beliefs all confirm that inaugural addresses function as cryptic texts demanding interpretation. The snapshot thesis cannot explain the author’s hermeneutic concerns; only the interpretive thesis fits all the evidence.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


Reading the Inaugurals 

         President Clinton's Inaugural Address this month is the 53 rd in the series that began in 1789. All are worth a read--not just the highlights, such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, and FDR. They will give you a feeling of being there, not as an omniscient historian of 1997 looking back at 1837 or 1897 but as an ordinary citizen who shares--and is limited by--the information, the concerns, and the values of those times. (Thanks to Columbia University, all the addresses can be found on the Web.) 

         Among all the past presidents and their speech writers there was only one literary genius: Lincoln. After 132 years, his second inaugural still brings tears to your eyes and chills your blood. None of the other inaugural addresses are in that league. But by and large they are dignified and intelligent speeches given by articulate men, each in touch with his times and aware that his inauguration was the most solemn occasion of his life. 

         The stance and style of the inaugurals seem to have gone through three phases. The first, lasting until Lincoln, was that of the modest, classic public servant. The second, lasting through William Howard Taft, was of the prosaic government executive. The third, in which we are still, is the phase of the assertive, theatrical leader-preacher. This classification is not waterproof. Theodore Roosevelt may belong in the third phase and Warren G. Harding-Calvin Coolidge-Herbert Hoover in the second. But the trend is clear. 

         On picking up Washington's first inaugural, one is immediately struck by the modesty. He had just been elected unanimously by the Electoral College. He was more respected than any subsequent president has been at the time of his inauguration. And what does he say? 

                         [T]he magnitude and difficulty of the trust to which the voice of my country called me, being sufficient to awaken in the wisest and most experienced of her citizens a distrustful scrutiny into his qualifications, could not but overwhelm with despondence one who (inheriting inferior endowments from nature and unpracticed in the duties of civil administration) ought to be peculiarly conscious of his own deficiencies.              

          None of his successors has made the point as forcefully as that. But echoes are to be found in almost every president for the next 68 years. (John Adams was an exception. He was apparently so envious of Washington that he spent a large part of his address spelling out his own excellent qualifications for the job.) That era ended with Lincoln. Subsequent inaugurals routinely contain protestations of humility, but they are perfunctory and do not sound sincere. 

         The antebellum modesty, while in part a reflection of the conventional etiquette of the time, may also have served a political objective: to alleviate the concerns of those who--in the early days of the republic--feared it might be transformed into a monarchy, and the president into a king. A little later, perhaps after 1820, a new worry arose. Would the power of the federal government be used to interfere with the "peculiar domestic institution" of the Southern states? The presidents' assurance of the limitation of their powers may have been intended to give comfort to those states. 

         Lincoln faced a different situation. With the South already seceding, he could only "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive. It was no time for modesty. Lincoln's successors inherited a federal government with much more authority--and more need to use it--than before the war, and they had less motivation to belittle themselves and their powers. 

         In the third phase, the Inaugural Address metamorphosed from describing the government's policy to inspiring the public's behavior. Presidents recognized--or, at least, believed--that the country had problems they ought to deal with but could not manage by using the instruments of government alone. Thus, in his first inaugural, Woodrow Wilson said: "At last a vision has been vouchsafed us of our life as a whole. We see the bad with the good, the debased and decadent with the sound and the vital. With this vision we approach new affairs." 

         If the country is debased and decadent, the cure has to come from uplifting the people, not from acts of government. Similar diagnoses and prescriptions appear in later inaugurals. 

          Presidents derived their license to serve as leader-preacher from Theodore Roosevelt's remark that the presidency was "a bully pulpit," a remark that did not appear in his Inaugural Address. The metaphor of the pulpit suggests not reading but oral and visual contact between the preacher and his flock. Radio and--even more--television made this possible on a national scale. A telltale sign of the leader-preacher inaugural is the use of the phrase, "Let us ... "--meaning, "You do as I say." This expression appears occasionally throughout the history of inaugurals, but it has hit its stride in recent years. John F. Kennedy repeated it 16 times in his Inaugural Address, and Richard Nixon has it 22 times in his second one. 

         The change in literary style from classical to colloquial can be demonstrated by one statistic. In all the inaugurals from Washington through James Buchanan, the average number of words per sentence was 44. From Lincoln to Wilson it was 34, and since Wilson it has been 25. I do not consider this a deterioration (this article has an average of 17 words per sentence), but it does reflect the change in the size and character of the audience and in the means of communication. William Henry Harrison could talk about the governments of Athens, Rome, and the Helvetic Confederacy and expect his audience to know what he was talking about. That wouldn't be true today. But Harrison's audience would not have known what the Internet was. 

         Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution. Kennedy's trumpet call, "Ask not what your country can do for you: Ask what you can do for your country," has an ironic history. In his inaugural, Harding, surely no model for Kennedy, had said, "Our most dangerous tendency is to expect too little of government, and at the same time do for it too little." And even before he became president, in a speech in 1916, Harding had said, "In the great fulfillment we must have a citizenship less concerned about what the government can do for it and more anxious about what it can do for the nation." 

         Many an issue frets its hour on the inaugural stage and then is heard no more. That includes the Indians, the coastal fortifications, territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, civil-service reform, polygamy, and Prohibition. Some subjects that you expect to appear, don't. Hoover's inaugural, March 4, 1929, gives no hint of economic vulnerability. Roosevelt's second inaugural, Jan. 20, 1937, contains no reference to Hitler or to Germany. But what is most amazing, at least to a reader in 1997, is the silence of the inaugurals on the subject of women. The word "women" does not appear at all until Wilson's first inaugural, and it always appears as part of the phrase "men and women," never as referring to any special concerns of women. Even Harding, the first president to be chosen in an election in which women voted nationally, does not remark on the uniqueness of the fact in his inaugural. 

          One subject that does get ample treatment is taxes. "Taxes," or some equivalent word, appears in 43 of the 52 inaugural addresses to date. Coolidge said in 1925: "The time is arriving when we can have further tax reduction. ... I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." Federal taxes were then about 3 percent of the gross domestic product. Ronald Reagan said essentially the same thing in 1981, when they were 20 percent. 

         The most disturbing aspect of the whole series of inaugurals is what is said and unsaid on the subject of race relations, which Arthur Schlesinger Jr. calls "the supreme American problem." The words "black," "blacks," "Negro," or "race" (as applied to blacks) do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes, 1877. James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" These were rhetorical questions, intended to get the answer "No one!"--as if there were not millions of slaves in America. 

         Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. 

         After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. 

         There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. We should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now, readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today. 

          

            POSTSCRIPT: To read Herbert Stein's analysis of President Clinton's second Inaugural Address, click .

Argument for “Inaugurals as Cryptic Texts Requiring Interpretation”  

I. The Author’s Emphasis on Omissions as Meaningful Evidence  
1. Persistent Silence on Critical Issues  
  • The author repeatedly flags what inaugurals omit—“women” until Wilson (<quote>The word "women" does not appear a</quote>) and “race” until 1877 (<quote>applied to blacks) do not appear at all until Rutherford Hayes,</quote>)—calling these silences “disturbing” and “amazing” (<quote>most disturbing aspect</quote>). In a mere snapshot theory, omissions would be seen as uninteresting lacunae, not as “negative evidence” demanding “cryptic” decoding of societal prejudices.  
2. “Moral obtuseness” and Future Judgment  
  • He warns that “readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today” (<quote>we should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now</quote>). A snapshot doesn’t anticipate future reinterpretation; only a cryptic-text model, with hidden biases, explains this forward‐looking hermeneutic concern.  

II. Analytical Tools Point to Interpretation, Not Plain Reporting  
1. Tripartite Phases as Hermeneutic Model  
  • The classification into three phases (modest servant, prosaic executive, leader-preacher) (<invalid_quote>The stance and style … seem to have gone through three phases</invalid_quote>) is not descriptive taxonomy for its own sake but a method for decoding shifts in ideological emphasis—“assert the power” versus “alleviate fears”—that informs how to read desired meanings “between the lines.”  
2. Sentence‐Length Statistics as Clues to Audience Framing  
  • The author’s statistical note—44 words/sentence early, 34 mid‐period, 25 modern (<invalid_quote>I do not consider this a deterioration … but it does reflect …</invalid_quote>)—serves as a code for identifying audience reach and rhetorical strategy. A snapshot view would simply note style change; cryptic reading demands interpreting intent behind brevity.  
3. Intertextual Allusions as Coded Continuities  
  • Presidents “mine their predecessors” for phrases (<quote>Ask not what y</quote> echoed from Harding). Such uncredited echoes function like literary ciphertext, drawing the informed reader’s attention to ideological inheritance and continuity. A mere snapshot wouldn’t treat repeated formulas as meaningful “reverberations.”  

III. Rebuttal of “Snapshot of Views” Thesis  
1. Plain Speech Would Not Hide Critical Subjects  
  • If inaugurals simply “mirror public concerns,” why must “race,” “women,” and economic warnings wait until “social pressures force discussion”? (<invalid_quote>FDR never mentioned it … Clinton’s only allusion …</invalid_quote>) The author treats these delays as evidence of “ignorance,” not “ordinary concerns,” implying inauguration texts conceal rather than reveal.  
2. Intelligibility to Contemporaries vs. Need for Historical Decoding  
  • Debater_B argues brevity implies openness. But the author commends “dignified and intelligent speeches” precisely because they require “reading in their entirety” to catch “subtle shifts” in phraseology and metaphor across eras (<quote>There is much more to ponder i</quote>). True cryptic messages can be plain enough to satisfy contemporaries yet encode deeper signals for later analysts.  
3. Leadership “Let us…” as Persuasive Manipulation  
  • The “Let us …” trope (<invalid_quote>Let us … 16 times …</invalid_quote>) signals a shift from reporting policy to “inspiring the public’s behavior,” a move the author sees as “metamorphosis” of the inaugural into a “bully pulpit.” This is active persuasion—“cryptic” in that it frames the people’s beliefs—rather than neutral snapshot of them.  

IV. Unified Hermeneutic Purpose  
1. The “Postsript” Invitation to Further Analysis  
  • The author’s infrastructure—phases, silences, statistics, metaphors, intertextuality—and his final gift of a “Postsript” link to an analysis of Clinton’s second inaugural (<invalid_quote>POSTSCRIPT: To read … click</invalid_quote>) demonstrate inaugurals are part of an ongoing interpretive project. A snapshot would not invite continual re‐analysis.  
2. Inaugurals as Loci of “Negative Evidence”  
  • Silences, omissions, rhetorical devices—treated by the author as equally informative—are the hallmarks of cryptic texts. Only by interpreting these gaps and codes can we reconstruct the “concerns, values, and information” that publics were not permitted or inclined to articulate, fulfilling the author’s stated aim to read “not as an omniscient historian” but as one attentive to contemporary “limitations” (<invalid_quote>not … omniscient historian … shares … limitations</invalid_quote>).  

Conclusion  
The author’s persistent focus on what inaugurals conceal, his analytical apparatus for decoding style and content, his forward‐looking hermeneutic admonitions, and his invitation to ongoing reinterpretation collectively show that inaugural addresses function as cryptic texts demanding interpretive keys. A mere “snapshot” theory cannot explain the weight he places on omissions and analytical models. Only the “cryptic way to interpret history” thesis accounts for the full range of the author’s evidence and objectives.

The antebellum modesty, while in part a reflection of the conventional etiquette of the time, may also have served a political objective: to alleviate the concerns of those who--in the early days of the republic--feared it might be transformed into a monarchy, and the president into a king. A little later, perhaps after 1820, a new worry arose. Would the power of the federal government be used to interfere with the "peculiar domestic institution" of the Southern states? The presidents' assurance of the limitation of their powers may have been intended to give comfort to those states. Lincoln faced a different situation. With the South already seceding, he could only "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution" by asserting the power of the federal government and his own power as chief executive. It was no time for modesty. Lincoln's successors inherited a federal government with much more authority--and more need to use it--than before the war, and they had less motivation to belittle themselves and their powers. In the third phase, the Inaugural Address metamorphosed from describing the government's policy to inspiring the public's behavior. Presidents recognized--or, at least, believed--that the country had problems they ought to deal with but could not manage by using the instruments of government alone. Thus, in his first inaugural, Woodrow Wilson said: "At last a vision has been vouchsafed us of our life as a whole. We see the bad with the good, the debased and decadent with the sound and the vital. With this vision we approach new affairs." If the country is debased and decadent, the cure has to come from uplifting the people, not from acts of government. Similar diagnoses and prescriptions appear in later inaugurals. This expression appears occasionally throughout the history of inaugurals, but it has hit its stride in recent years. John F. Kennedy repeated it 16 times in his Inaugural Address, and Richard Nixon has it 22 times in his second one. The change in literary style from classical to colloquial can be demonstrated by one statistic. In all the inaugurals from Washington through James Buchanan, the average number of words per sentence was 44. From Lincoln to Wilson it was 34, and since Wilson it has been 25. I do not consider this a deterioration (this article has an average of 17 words per sentence), but it does reflect the change in the size and character of the audience and in the means of communication. William Henry Harrison could talk about the governments of Athens, Rome, and the Helvetic Confederacy and expect his audience to know what he was talking about. That wouldn't be true today. But Harrison's audience would not have known what the Internet was. Presidents and their speech writers have mined their predecessors for memorable words and repeated them without attribution. Kennedy's trumpet call, "Ask not what your country can do for you: Ask what you can do for your country," has an ironic history. In his inaugural, Harding, surely no model for Kennedy, had said, "Our most dangerous tendency is to expect too little of government, and at the same time do for it too little." And even before he became president, in a speech in 1916, Harding had said, "In the great fulfillment we must have a citizenship less concerned about what the government can do for it and more anxious about what it can do for the nation." Many an issue frets its hour on the inaugural stage and then is heard no more. That includes the Indians, the coastal fortifications, territorial expansion, the Isthmus Canal, civil-service reform, polygamy, and Prohibition. Some subjects that you expect to appear, don't. Coolidge said in 1925: "The time is arriving when we can have further tax reduction. ... I am opposed to extremely high rates, because they produce little or no revenue, because they are bad for the country, and, finally, because they are wrong." James Monroe asked in 1817, "On whom has oppression fallen in any quarter of our Union? Who has been deprived of any right of person or property?" Before the Civil War the word "slavery" appears only in the Inaugural Address of Martin Van Buren, 1837, and Buchanan, 1857, and then only as something that, pursuant to the Constitution and in order to preserve the Union, should not be interfered with. But although generally unmentionable, the subject was boiling, and would boil over in 1861. After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. speeches.content:
1. Restating My Thesis  
   • “Inaugural addresses present a snapshot of the views and beliefs of their time,” not puzzles to be decoded. The author urges readers to experience “being there … as an ordinary citizen who shares … the concerns, and the values of those times” <quote>Reading the Inaugurals</quote>. Snapshot implies transparency to contemporaries; cryptic messaging would require hidden codes, contradicting this call for direct engagement.  

2. Omissions Reflect Social Norms, Not Codes  
   A. Women and Race Silences  
      • The author is “amazed … at what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed” regarding “silence … on the subject of women” and race <invalid_quote>silence … moral obtuseness</invalid_quote>. This amazement underscores ignorance, not intentional concealment. He laments these omissions as evidence of “ignorance,” not as encrypted truth awaiting decryption.  
   B. Public Comfort, Not Clandestine Messaging  
      • Early presidents “alleviate … fears” of monarchy or federal overreach by professing humility <invalid_quote>alleviate the concerns … feared … monarchy</invalid_quote>. This reassurance would be meaningless if it concealed true intentions. It is plainly stated to gain trust, consistent with snapshot openness.

3. Style and Statistics Confirm Clarity  
   A. Sentence-Length Trends  
      • The shift from 44 to 25 words per sentence “reflect[s] the change in the size and character of the audience” <invalid_quote>from 44 … to 25 words per sentence</invalid_quote>. Shorter sentences serve intelligibility, not obscurity. The author praises clarity (“this article has an average of 17 words per sentence”). Cryptic texts would grow more obscure, not clearer.  
   B. “Let us …” as Direct Appeal  
      • “Let us” appears 16 times in Kennedy’s address and 22 in Nixon’s, harnessing mass media’s reach (“Radio and … television made this possible”) to mobilize citizens <quote>bully pulpit</quote>. Mobilization presumes comprehension, not cryptic persuasion.

4. Refuting the “Cryptic” Interpretation  
   A. Analytical Tools Are Descriptive, Not Decoding  
      • The three-phase model and topic-frequency counts serve to **map** changing concerns, not to **decode** hidden messages. If the author intended cryptic readings, he would propose specific ciphers or keys; instead, he invites comparisons to known historical events (e.g., Civil War, Depression).  
   B. Future Readers’ Critique Implies Evolving Norms, Not Hidden Intent  
      • The postscripts about future readers shaking heads <invalid_quote>50 or 100 years … shake their heads</invalid_quote> emphasize that inaugurals are transparent to their own era yet limited by it. This demonstrates snapshots tied to temporal values, not secret content.  

5. Debater_A’s Misreadings  
   A. Omissions as Evidence of Ignorance  
      • Debater_A treats omissions as “negative evidence” requiring interpretation. The author labels these omissions “unmentionable” and criticizes them, revealing they are blind spots, not deliberate codes.  
   B. Intertextual Allusions Are Homage, Not Cryptography  
      • Repeated phrases like “Ask not what…” hark back to predecessors to inspire continuity and patriotism. No attribution signals oral tradition and rhetorical flourish, not secret persuasion.  
   C. Hermeneutic Claims Undermine Plain Language  
      • Debater_A’s insistence on “hermeneutic apparatus” ignores the author’s emphasis on “dignified and intelligent speeches given by articulate men” <quote>dignified and intelligent</quote> accessible to “ordinary citizen.”  

6. Conclusion  
   • The author consistently treats inaugurals as public, intelligible speeches reflecting contemporaneous **information, concerns, and values** <invalid_quote>ordinary citizen … concerns … values</invalid_quote>. Style changes, topic choices, and silences all illustrate the eras’ prevailing norms and limitations. The snapshot thesis fully accounts for both what is said and unsaid; the cryptic thesis conflicts with the author’s repeated emphasis on openness and intelligibility.

After the Civil War, it is in the inaugurals of Hayes, James Garfield (1881), and Benjamin Harrison (1889) that we find the most explicit and positive discussion of the need to convert into reality the rights and freedom granted to the "freedmen" on paper by the 13 th , 14 th , and 15 th amendments. Garfield's was the strongest among these. (He had been a student at Williams College in the 1850s, 80 years before me, when the college had been a station on the underground railway.) But the subject then began to fade. William McKinley said in his first Inaugural Address, March 4, 1897, "Lynchings must not be tolerated in a great and civilized country like the United States," but he said it without horror. Taft raised the subject of race relations in 1909 only to express satisfaction at the progress that had been made. And then the subject disappeared. FDR never mentioned it in any of his four inaugurals. After World War II the subject came back to inaugural addresses, but in a weak and abstract form. That is true even of the presidents we think of as being most concerned with race relations in America--like Harry Truman, Lyndon Johnson, and Bill Clinton. Perhaps each thought he had made a sufficient statement by having a black woman--Marian Anderson, Leontyne Price, or Maya Angelou--perform at his ceremony. In Clinton's first inaugural, the only allusion to the race problem is in this sentence: "From our revolution, the Civil War, to the Great Depression to the civil rights movement, our people have always mustered the determination to construct from these crises the pillars of our history." I recall this not to suggest that their concern was not deep and sincere, but only to indicate what is acceptable to say in a speech intended to appeal to the values shared by Americans. There is much more to ponder in these speeches than I have suggested here. There is much to be proud of, in what we have endured and achieved, in the peaceful transference of power, and in the reasonableness and moderation of the presidents we have elected. But there is also much humility to be learned. We look back with amazement at the ignorance and moral obtuseness revealed by what our past leaders have said and our past citizens believed. We should recognize that 50 or 100 years from now, readers will shake their heads at what we are saying and believing today.
